author: Richard Bailey
content: ‘HMS’ Rose (airdraft 130′) made many passages under the Brooklyn Bridge (127′). We always housed the main t’gallant mast, even when a low tide might have permitted unhoused passage. As I liked to say, it’s better to be paranoid than dismasted. I offer no opinion in the Cuauht√©moc matter. But I dread the the likely constant replay of the video(s), just as I dread the Cisne Branco/bridge videos.

author: Peter Wright
content: The masts also hit the suspended maintenance gantry, a frightening prospect, I hope there were no casualties there.

author: Jimmy
content: Depending on wind direction and velocity, the ships sail structure could have contributed forces to direct the ship aft.

author: D. Peter Boucher, Kt. SMOM, International Master Mariner
content:
Clearly safety policies will require review. Perhaps a change in manned rigging in Port areas might require to be changed.

Deepest sympathy to all onboard and the families of those lost and injured.

Good Watch

author: Craig Northacker
content: I sailed out of South Street Seaport as a crew member on the schooner Pioneer. So sad to see this happen.
